title: General Wave Properties: Definitions, Calculations, and Applications
subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a transverse wave?
options: A wave where the particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation
A wave where the particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation
A wave that requires a medium to travel through
A wave that can travel through a vacuum
questions.explanation: In transverse waves, particle displacement is perpendicular to wave direction. Examples: light, water waves.

questions.question: What is the definition of wavelength?
options: Distance between two consecutive points in phase on a wave
Time taken for one complete wave to pass a point
Number of complete waves passing a point per second
Maximum displacement from the rest position
questions.explanation: Wavelength (λ) is measured between two consecutive crests, troughs, or any two points in phase.

questions.question: If a wave has a frequency of 50 Hz and a wavelength of 0.5 m, what is its wave speed?
questions.explanation: Wave speed v = f × λ = 50 Hz × 0.5 m = 25 m/s.

questions.question: What is the period of a wave with frequency 20 Hz?
Which type of wave can travel through a vacuum?
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic waves (e.g., light, radio) can travel through a vacuum; mechanical waves require a medium.

questions.question: In a water wave, a buoy moves up and down 10 times in 5 seconds. What is the frequency?
What is the amplitude of a wave?
options: Maximum displacement from the rest position
questions.explanation: Amplitude is the maximum displacement from equilibrium, related to wave energy.

questions.question: If a sound wave has a speed of 340 m/s and a wavelength of 0.68 m, what is its frequency?
Which wave property determines loudness for sound and brightness for light?
questions.explanation: Amplitude affects loudness (sound) and brightness (light); energy is proportional to amplitude squared.

questions.question: What happens to wavelength if frequency doubles and wave speed remains constant?
questions.explanation: v = fλ. If v constant and f doubles, λ must halve.

questions.question: Which diagram shows correct labeling of amplitude and wavelength on a transverse wave?
options: Amplitude: vertical arrow from rest to crest; Wavelength: horizontal arrow crest to crest
Amplitude: horizontal arrow crest to crest; Wavelength: vertical arrow rest to crest
Amplitude: from trough to crest; Wavelength: from crest to trough
Amplitude and wavelength are both horizontal arrows
questions.explanation: Amplitude is vertical, wavelength is horizontal between identical points.

questions.question: A wave travels 60 m in 2 seconds. If its frequency is 10 Hz, what is its wavelength?
questions.explanation: First find speed: v = distance/time = 60/2 = 30 m/s. Then λ = v/f = 30/10 = 3 m.

questions.question: What type of wave are sound waves in air?
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal; particles vibrate parallel to wave direction.

questions.question: If a wave's period is 0.2 s, how many waves pass a point in 10 seconds?
questions.explanation: Number of waves = total time / period = 10 s ÷ 0.2 s = 50.

questions.question: Which application uses reflection of waves?
questions.explanation: Echo sounding uses reflection of sound waves to measure underwater depth. Radio broadcasting relies on transmission, not reflection. X-ray imaging depends on absorption, not reflection. Therefore, only echo sounding primarily uses wave reflection.
